headline.main: Court Rules U.S. Can't Pursue $280 Billion as Tobacco Penalty

docs.abstract: US appeals court delivers major victory to nation's leading tobacco companies, ruling that government cannot force them to turn over $280 billion in profits if trial court finds that companies engaged in conspiracy of fraud and deceit in promoting smoking ; 2-to-1 decision strikes at heart of government's biggest legal effort to punish cigarette makers; it reverses ruling by Judge Gladys Kessler; Judge David B Sentelle, in writing majority opinion, found that 1970 Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act does not allow government to recover illegal profits as way to prevent and restrain future violations (M)

keywords.value: RACKETEER INFLUENCED AND CORRUPT ORGANIZATION ACT
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court delivered a major victory to the nation's leading tobacco companies on Friday, ruling that the government cannot force them to turn over $280 billion in profits if a trial court finds that the companies engaged in a conspiracy of fraud and deceit to promote smoking. The 2-to-1 decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia strikes at the heart of the government's biggest legal effort ever to punish cigarette makers.
docs.snippet: The court ruled the government could not collect $280 billion it alleges the tobacco industry earned through fraud.

headline.main: For a Trial Lacking in Drama, a Star Witness, of Sorts

docs.abstract: Jeffrey S Wigand, former vice president for Brown & Williamson Tobacco USA, takes stand in government's $280 billion racketeering case against major cigarette companies; in 1995, he played crucial role in $246 billion settlement between tobacco companies and 46 states that sued companies to recoup medical costs from illnesses associated with smoking; he was highest-ranking American business executive to testify against his employer; 1999 motion picure The Insider dramatized his decision to break confidentiality agreement and publicly discuss business practices that he belived violated public trust; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: After a parade of witnesses generally unknown beyond their narrow roles in the nation's tobacco wars, Jeffrey S. Wigand took the stand on Monday in the government's $280 billion racketeering case against the major cigarette companies. By comparison, this was a star turn. As a former vice president and head of research and development for Brown & Williamson Tobacco USA, Mr. Wigand became one of the highest-ranking American business executives to testify against his employer when he gave a deposition in a tobacco case in Mississippi.
docs.snippet: Jeffrey Wigand, of "The Insider" fame, is testifying in the government's $280 billion racketeering case against the major cigarette companies.
